div.head: THE EGYPTIAN GAZETTE
No. 7,466] ALEXANDRIA, THURSDAY, April 12, 1906. [SIX PAGES P.T. 1.
Peninsular and Oriental S. N. Company.
div.p: Summer Rates will be charged from 2 May to 31 October.

For the convenience of families and others, a large portion of each ship's accommodation has been reserved for Egypt, so that Berths can be definitely engaged at once, as if the voyage were commencing at Port Said. Plans can be seen at the Offices of the Company's Agents.

The through Steamers for Marseilles and London are intended to leave Port Said after the arrival of the 11 a.m. train from Cairo, every Tuesday for the present except the MONGOLIA, which is taking passengers to the Anglo-French Naval Review, and will not wait at Port-Said on 24/25 July. A steam tender will meet the train to convey passengers to the ship.
The Brindisi Express Steamers leave Port Said directly the Indian Mails arrive. Passengers can go on board the evening before. The Fare remains as usual.
For all further information apply to the Company's Agents,
Messrs. THOS. COOK & SON (Egypt) Ltd. CAIRO.
GEORGE ROYLE, Esq. PORT-SAID.
Messrs. HABELDEN & Co. ALEXANDRIA.
F. G. DAVIDSON, Superintendent P. & O. S. N. Company in Egypt SUEZ.

div.head: Orient-Royal Mail Line.
div.p: REDUCED SUMMER FARES FROM MAY TO OCTOBER INCLUSIVE.
OUTWARD to AUSTRALIA.
R.M.S. "Oruba" will leave Suez about October 5
R.M.S "Ophir" will leave Suez about October 19.
HOMEWARD to NAPLES, MARSEILLES, GIBRALTAR, PLYMOUTH, LONDON, TILBURY.
R.M.S. "Ortona" will leave Port Said October 23
R.M.S. "Oroya" will leave Port Said October 8
Passengers returning by the Line obtain one-third rebate off the above fares if leaving England before the end of October.

Wm. STAPLEDON & Sons, PORT SAID and PORT-TEWFIK (Suez). 31-12-906

div.head: BIBBY LINE MAIL STEAMERS.
div.p: Special Reduced Rates During Summer Season,
OUTWARDS to COLOMBO, TUTICORIN, etc., and RANGOON. Departures from Suez.
S.S. Derbyshire 6,635 tons, leaves about July 20.
S.S. Lancashire 4,244 tons, leaves about August 3.
HOMEWARDS to MARSEILLES and LONDON. Departures from Port Said.
S.S. Worcestershire 7,160 tons, leaves about July 26.
S.S. Yorkshire 4,196 tons leaves about August 9.
FARES from Port Said to Marseilles £12.0.0, London £17.0.0, Colombo £32.10.0, Rangoon £37.10.0.
Agents Cairo: THOS. COOK & SON. Suez & Port Said : WM. STAPLEDON & SONS,

div.head: KHEDIVIAL MAIL LINE.
div.p: FAST BRITISH PASSENGER STEAMERS
GREECE - TURKEY LINE.
Express Steamers leave Alexandria every Wednesday at 4 p.m. for PIRAEUS, SMYRNA, MITYLENE, and CONSTANTINOPLE, in connection with Orient Express train-de-luxe for Vienna, Paris, and London.
PALESTINE - SYRIA LINE.

Fast steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 6 p.m., and Port Said every Sunday at 6 p.m., for JAFFA (for Jerusalem), CAIFFA (for Nazareth), BEYROUT (for Damascus), TRIPOLI, ALEXANDRETTA, MESSINA, continuing in alternate weeks to LARNACA and LIMASSOL (Cyprus).
RED SEA LINE.

Steamers leave Suez fortnightly on Wednesday at 6 p.m. for JEDDAH, SUAKIN, MASSOWAH, HODBIDAH, and ADEN ; and in the intervening weeks for PORT SUDAN and SUAKIN direct. Calls will be made at TOR (for Mount Sinai) as required.
N.B.—Deck chairs provided for the use of passengers, excellent cuisine and table wine free.
Steamer plans may be seen and passages booked at the Company's Agencies at Alexandria, Cairo, Port Said, and Suez, or at THOS. COOK & SON or other Tourist Agency.

div.head: The Moss S.S. Company, Ltd.
div.p: For LIVERPOOL calling at MALTA (Messrs. JAMES MOSS & Co. 31, James St, Liverpool, Managers.)

*Second class accommodation only, unless specially reserved.—Fares : Alexandria to Liverpool, 1st, £14 Single, £25 Return. 2nd, £9 Single, £15 Return.—To Malta, 1st, £5 Single, £9 Return, 2nd, £3 Single, £5 Return.—Return tickets available for six months.
S.S. Seti now on the berth, will sail on or about Monday, July 17, to be followed by S.S. Menes.
S.S Tabor for Havre via Malta to sail about Saturday l5th inst.
Through freight rates on cotton, etc., to Lancashire inland towns, Boston, New York and other U.S.A. towns, obtained on application. Cargo taken by special agreement only.
Passenger Tickets also issued inclusive of Railway fare through to and from Cairo. Particulars on application to
R. J. MOSS & Co., Alexandria, Agents.

S.S. RANGOON 6000 Tons will leave PORT SAID about July 23 for London.
S.S. BURMA 5600 Tons will leave PORT SAID about August 6 for London.
S.S. ARRACAN 5800 Tons will leave PORT SAID about August 20 for Liverpool
Due in LONDON or LIVERPOOL 12 days thereafter.

div.p: (EGYPT), LIMITED, HEAD OFFICE—LUDGATE CIRCUS—LONDON.

Alexandria, Port-Said, Suez, Luxor, Assuan, Haifa, & Khartum.
GENERAL RAILWAY AND STEAMSHIP AGENTS. BANKERS.
BAGGAGE AND FORWARDING AGENTS.
Officially appointed & Sole Agents in Cairo to the P.&O. S.N. Co.

RESIDENTS IN EGYPT proceeding to Europe for the summer are requested to apply to our offices for information respecting their Passages, where steamer plans may be consulted and Berths secured by all Lines of Steamers to all parts of the Globe; arrangements can also be made for the collection and forwarding of their baggage and clearance at port of arrival.

CIRCULAR NOTES issued payable at the current rate of exchange in all the principal cities of Europe. Cook's Interpreters in uniform are present at the principal Railway stations and Landing-places in Europe to assist passengers holding their travelling tickets.

Large and splendidly appointed steamers belonging to the Co. leave Cairo thrice weekly, between November and March, for Luxor, Assouan and Wady-Halfa in connection with trains de luxe to Khartoum. Moderate fares.
FREIGHT SERVICE, Steamers leave Cairo every Saturday and Tuesday for Assouan and Halfa.
Special Steamers and Dahabeahs for private parties.
Special arrangements for tour in PALESTINE, SYRIA and the DESERT, Lowest Rates.
Best camp equipment in the country! 10 12-904

La National Bank of Egypt reçoit des dépots à termes fixes, fait des avances et ouvre des comptes courants sur titres, valeurs et marchandises. Elle s'occupe de l'achat et de la vente d'effets sur l'Etranger, de l'escompte, ainsi que de toutes opérations de Banque. 31-12-904

div.head: Austrian Lloyd's Steam Navigation
div.p: Alexandria-Brindisi-Trieste (Venice).

Weekly Express Mail Service. Steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 4 p.m. arrive at Brindisi, Tuesday 5 a.m. in time for express to Milan, Lucerne, Paris, Vienna, Berlin, and London, leaving Brindisi 7 a.m. Arrival Trieste Wednesday about 11 a.m. in connection with Train de Luxe Trieste-Vienna-Ostende. Passengers reach London every Friday 4.50 p.m.
Fortnightly Service: Alexandria-Brindisi & Trieste Line.
Steamer leaves Alexandria on or about 10 and 24 October, 7 and 21 November, 5 and 19 December.
Syrian-Cyprus-Caramanian Line.
Steamer leaves Alexandria on or about 8 and 22 October, 5 and 19 November, 3, 17 and 31 December.
Syrian-Caramanian Line.
Steamer leaves Alexandria on or about 1, 15 and 29 October, 12 and 26 November, 10 and 24 December.
Far East Lines.
Departures from Port Said: To Suez, Aden, Bombay, Colombo, Penang, Singapore, Hong-Kong, Shanghai, Yokohama and Kobé, 4 October, 3 November.
To Suez, Aden and Bombay accelerated service about 8 October, 8 Nov., 8 Dec.
To Suez, Aden, Karachi, Colombo, Madras, Rangoon, and Calcutta about 19 Oct, 3, 19 Nov., 19 Dec 4 p.m.
To Suez, Aden, Karachi and Bombay about 13 Nov., 1 Dec (Winter Line).
East African Line.
Departures from Port Said: To Suez, Aden, Mombassa, Zanzibar, Beira, Delagoa-Bay, and Durban about 3 Oct., 2 Nov., 3 Dec..
For information apply to the Agents, Alexandria, Port Said and Suez, Thos. Cook & Son, Ld., Leon Heller, Cairo Agent, 24, Sharia Maghraby, (Telephone 192), Cairo; F. Tedeschi, Helouan.

div.head: SUDAN GOVERNMENT RAILWAYS.
div.p: CAIRO-KHARTOUM SUMMER MAIL SERVICE.--SUMMER TIME-TABLE 1906.
Commencing from 1st of April, 1906, until further notice

‡Sleeping and Dining Cars. — During the month of April Sleeping and Dining Care trains leave Cairo for Luxor on Wednesdays, Mondays and Saturdays at 6.30 p.m. and Luxor for Cairo on Sundays, Tuesdays and Thursdays at 6.30 p.m.

From 1st of May 1908, these trains will be suppressed, but Dining and Sleeping Care will be attached to the ordinary night Tains from Cairo and Luxor three times a week, on the same above mentioned days. 14-6-907

div.head: THE ANGLO-EGYPTIAN BANK, LIMITED.
div.p: LONDON, PARIS ALEXANDRIA, CAIRO MALTA, GIBRALTAR, TANTAH, AND PORT SAID.
Subscribed Capital JS1.500,000
Reserve Fund... 500,000
The Anglo-Egyptian Bank. Limited, undertakes every description of banking business on the most favourable conditions.
Current accounts opened with commercial homes and private individuals in conformity with the custom of Bankers.
Fixed deposits for one year certain received at 8 per cent. per annum. Deposits at interest for shorter periods are also received at rates to be agreed upon.
Letters of Credit for the use of travellers are issued payable in all parts of the World.
Approved bills discounted.
Bills, documentary invoices, etc, collected.
Drafts and telegraphic transfers issued payable all over the World.
Foreign exchange bought and sold.
Advances made upon approved securities and upon cotton, cotton-seed, sugar and other merchandise.
The purchase and sale of stocks and shares on the London Stock Exchange; and on the local and Continental Bourses, undertaken.

Customers can deposit their valuables, bonds, etc., for safe custody in the Bank's fire-proof strong-rooms, and the Bank will attend to the collection of the coupons and drawn bonds so deporited as they fall due.
Mercantile credits issued.
Annuities, pensions, dividends, etc., collected.
All farther particulars and information can be obtained on application.
The officers and clerks of the Bank are pledged to secrecy as to the transactions of customers. 18-9-905

div.head: (CYPRUS.) THE OLYMPUS HOTEL.
div.p: On Mount Troodos : 6,000 feet above sea level. Perfect climate. Magnificent scenery. Season June to October. For inclusive terms and information apply to the Manager, Cyprus Hotel Company, Limassol, Cyprus.

div.head: Icilma.
div.p: ARABIC FOR "FLOWS THE WATER."

Icilma Fluor Cream is the only cream that contains no grease nor oil. Deliciously scented it cleanses the pores of the skin as nothing else can do, makes it pearly white, gives life to the tissues, elasticity to the muscles, and a deliciously cool feeling to the skin.

Its unique properties are due to Icilma Natural Water so that it may well be called Nature's Skin Food and the skin requires nothing else to give it the necessary vitality, to preserve it from sunburn, heat, cold or the effects of hard water, to prevent and cure the minor irritations due to overheated blood, and to preserve the youthful fresh look to which hot climates are so fatal.
Invaluable for immediately curing mosquito and insect bites and for greatly preventing them.
Depot for Egypt : J. McGregor, Chemist.
Alexandria, Cairo, Ibrahimieh, Luxor, Icilma Co. Ltd., 142, Gray's Inn Road, London, W. C.

div.head: THE EGYPTIAN GAZETTE.
div.p: SUBSCRIPTIONS.—Alexandria, Cairo, and the Interior of Egypt (including delivery in Alexandria or postage to subscriber's address) P.T. 231½ per annum, P.T. 116 for six months, P.T. 80 for three months. To other countries in the Postal Union P.T. 273 (£2.16s.) per annum. Six months P.T. 136½ (£1.8s.), three months P.T. 92 (£0.19s.) N.B.—Subscriptions commence from the 1st or 16th of any month.

ADVERTISEMENTS.—P.T. 4 per line. Minimum charge P.T. 20. Births, Marriages, or Deaths, not exceeding three lines, P.T. 20. Every additional line P.T. 10. Notices in news column P.T. 20 per line. Contracts entered into for standing advertisements.
SUBSCRIPTIONS and ADVERTISEMENTS are due in advance. P.O. Orders and Cheques to be made payable to the Editor and Manager, Rowland Snelling, Alexandria.
London Offices : 36, New Broad-street. B.C.
THE EGYPTIAN GAZETTE can be obtained in London at our office, 36, New Broad Street, E.C., and also at Messrs. May & Williams 160, Piccadilly, W.
THE "EGYPTIAN GAZETTE" IS PRINTED ON PAPER MANUFACTURED AND SUPPLIED BY THE LONDON PAPER MILLS Co., LIMITED (SALES OFFICE: 27, CANNON STREET, E.C.)

div.head:
VESUVIUS INVISIBLE.
HORRIBLE GREY DESOLATION.
WHOLE REGION UNDER DENSE PALL.
HEAVY DEATH-ROLL

div.p: Ottajana is smothered with ashes. The popa- lation of 200 souls are perishing. The volcano resumed activity yesterday evening and is emitting showers of sulphur and sand. Torre del Greco and Torre Annunziata are ont off from Naples. Several correspondents there are anable to leave.
14 dead and 124 injured have been extricat ed from the market here. FIF199 105 bodies have been recovered from, the rains of the church of San Giuseppe..
The King and Queen have given £4,000 to the fund for the sufferera
(Reuter)

The country for miles around Vesovins présents a picture of horrible grey desolation, no vestige of green remsing all towns and villages are more or less eh-buried, some of them six feet deep, recalling the Pompei lisaster. Estimates of the total death roll vary rom five to eight hundred. To-day's accounte re not reassuring. The whole region is under deuse pall; Vesuvias is invisible; frequent arricanes of rain, stones, and ashes are taking place.
The King and Queen have arrived here. (R.)
The King and Queen returned from Rome to isit the victims. The lava to-day is motionless. One hundred and fifty bodies have been reco- ered from the rains of the San Giuseppe hurch. (Harias)

div.head:
EDUCATION BILL.
THE PRIMATE'S ACTION.
div.p: The Archbishop of Canterbury has ferued that is practically a manifesto against the Education Bill, in which he declares that hatchmen must take immediate couneel in an mergency of so grays and far-reaching effect.. The Archbishop of Canterbary presided at rivate meeting of bishops at Lambeth Palace o discuss the Education Bill. (Router)

div.head: PRINCE ARTHUR IN CANADA
div.p: Prince Arthur of Connaught. has arrived ere. His Royal Highness met with a splendid eception all through Western Canada and xpressed himself as astonished with the mar- rellous progress of the country. (Reuter)
Inst

div.head: BREAD RIOT AT MESHED.
div.p: (Beater). The disturbanos at Meshed was s nere bread riot in which three people were illed, none of whom were Europeans. (Router)

div.head: THE RUSSIAN PARLIAMENT.
div.p: It appears certain that the Constitutional Democrate hase an immense mejority in the Lower House of the National Assembly, and are already drafting bills of a pronounced literal type. The Upper House is however overwhe mirgly Conservative. Router)
deida

div.head: THE HAGUE CONFERENCE
div.p: The United States, supported by France, sked Russia to postpone the Hague Confer ence in order to prevent its clashing with the Pan-American congress at Rio Janeiro.
The King and Queen of England have
Arrived here.
(Route)
The King and Queen of England have arrived. (Harde)

div.head: MONEY AND SHARE MARKET.
div.p: The Money Market
London, April 6,

The Bank rate was yesterday reduced from 4% to 3%, after having stood at the former figure for about six months. Right up to the time of announcement of the reduction there. was great doubt in the City as to what action would be taken by the Bank directors. Of course, there would have been much disap pointment had the decision been other than it was, but nevertheless the directors would have had ample justification had they main- tained the higher rate, in view of the state of the French exchange cheque on Paris being then very weak at 25.12. In addition to this, all the available gold in the market was being bought on French account, sovereigns were being taken from the Bank for shipment to South America, and the reserve showed a reduction of two millions:

The fact that the 4% rate was no longer effective no doubt brought its downfall, aided by the disbursement of Government fands, in. the shape of the Consol dividend and the repayment of two millions of Treasury Bille, bat nevertheless, call money, which in the morning commanded 21% to 24%, hardened in the afternoon to 8% and the India Council renewed loans for a month at 23% To-day. loans for the week command 23%, and the discount rate stands at 3% for two and three months bills, with a stiffening tendency.

The Bank return, in addition to the reduc tion in the reserve mentioned above, shows decline of 23,672,000 in Public Deposits. This release of Government funds apparently enabled the market to repay its indebtedness to the Bank, se evidenced by a reduction of £3,200,000 in Other Securities." The "Other 00,000 Deposita", are only £869,000 lower, and the proportion is a shade higher at 451%.
This is anything but a strong return for this. time of the year, and with the French obeque to-day at 25.11, and call money at 19% in New York, the outlook is not all that could be desired.
The Stock Markets,

Notwithstanding the réduction in the Bank rate the stock markets have not responded with increased activity. In fact, yesterday was one of the dullest days ever experienced. The truth of it is that very large issues are impending. Not only Rossis, but. Germany also is under stood to be on the point of issuing a big loan. With regard to the Russian loan, it is said that the dealing in this has already began in Paris, and that the bonds are likely to be issued at a very favourable price, and to go off without difficulty. The issue price is spoken of as 89, and this will of course prove very tempting. In addition to these, there have been placed in London very large amounts of American railway bonds. Such transactions have been very unusual of late years, and these are no doubt the result of the bareness of money in the American markets, These new investments are more attractive than many of those which show an excellent security and a good rate of interest, but which have already had their flatter, and are mostly in the hands of disap Pointed underwriters:
Consols.

The settlement in Console commenced on Tuesday, and the making up price shows a further advance on the previous account of thus making an increase for the two months of. The gilt-edged market has moderately appreciated the better conditions now ruling, and Console closed last night at 90 for cash, after being higher. The closing quotation to-day is 90. DA
Foreign Bonds.

The demand for Japanese stocks referred to in our last letter continued in the early part of this week, bat this has now apparently been satisfied for the present, and interest in the bonds disappeared. Japanese Foura leave off abont higher on the week at 01 Russian securities have been adversely affected by the rumours respecting the new loan, and have lost the good position they had maintained for over a fortnight. The price of the Four per cent is now 83, with little demand for them.
Home Ralls,

On the subject of home railways there is little to say. The market is lifeless, chiefly Owing to the rumour that the Government. intend establishing an eight-hour day for rail- way employés, a step which would hopelessly cripple the dividenda of many companies. Whilst it is not at all likely that, this will happen, the bare possibility frightens intending. buyers.
Americans.
A very firm tone, has characterised this

market, and prices are higher all round, many of the stocks showing advances of between two and three points. Union Pacifics have been specially favogred, and the quotation for these last night was no less than 5 higher than a week go. The closing prices are as follows: Aitchison, 96 Baltimore, 116 ; Canadian Pacific, 1773 longo and Milwaukee, 182; Brie, 46 xd,linois Gentral, 178.); Louis ville, 155 New York Central, 150; Pennsyl vania hares, 72 ; Philadelphia and Reading, 74. Eonthern Pacific, 704; Union Pacifio, 167 fx d
tape.

Beyptian market has been very firm but quiet since our last, although Dalta Land and Investment have again advanced on very heavy buying from Egypt. An enormons quan tity of the shares have hanged hands, and they close at the highest, National Bank of Egypt are ex-dividend at 27 and Agricul turals are very good at 10. The reference are 10 and the Debentures 931 Daira Banieb Ordinary are slightly easier at 18 and the. Deferred at 106. Egyptian Investment and Agency are a good market at premiam, bat Trust and Investment are rath r offered at fr premium. Land and General are again in demand at 3 premium, Delta. Preference Bearer have changed hands at 121. Union. Foncière rose rapidly to 7 buyers, but have relapsed again to 6. Bank of Abyssinia are unchanged at premium.
F

Land Bank of Egypt have been good, and close 91 Salt and Soda are offered at 24., although there is no market worth speaking of. There is little business in Egyptian Marke's, the price being nominally 1. Bank of Ron- mania rose quietly, to 10, but close very doubtful at 10.middle. Corporation of Western Egypt at I premium and Daira Sagar at 41 are quite unchanged.. Egyptian Estates close at over 2, and the Deferred at 121
The coming meeting of the Egyptian Estates is much looked for, and it is hinted that the report hardly gives a true idea of the won derful success of this undertaking.
Mining.
The South African market is still under a wet blanket, and yesterday, the eve of the carry over, there was no business passing. Prices remain at about last week's levels.

The Egyptian section was unmentioned until yesterday, when Egyptian Options were a good feature, and closed. 11/32 ap.at 1 It is understood. some news as to their success is shortly to be forthcoming. Nile Valleys are 68., neglected at that.

div.head: ARMY AND NAVY..."
div.p: (FROM OUR CORRESPONDENT)

London, April 2. The Secretary for War states that the Army Estimates for the financial year on which we have just started bears charges to the amount of £280,000 for the troopa in Egypt and the Sudan. Since 1897, the amount incurred under the Military Works Loans Act is £166,000 in Egypt.

The wildly absurd story is going the rounds that Sir Hector Macdonald is not only alive, but was very mach so during the late Russo- Japanese War, and he is credited with being no other than the invincible Kuroki. The story goes that when Sir Hector came home on the journey which was to be his last, he had been asked by the Jap authorities to join their army. Lord Roberts refused bis

notion and Sir Hector went away, and pre- tended to commit suicide, and re-appeared as General Kuroki. It may be recalled that Sir Hector's body was never seen by any one who knew him in life, and that Kuroki-never got a public reception after his great victories and that his death has been reported at various times, although he has shown the knack of torning up in action when he was. wanted. Whoever eet this extraordinary yarn. in circulation séema to have forgotten how simple it would have been for the great but unfortunate Sir Heator to have resigned his commission and have joined any army he pleased. Sir Hector was the last man to disappear under the shadow of a shameful charge.

With reference to a resolution passed by the Council of the British Empire League urging the Admiralty to place no unnecessary limit on the numbers to be enrolled in the Colonial nával reserves, either in Newfoundland or Australis, and to afford adequate provision in all cases for their service at sea with a warship, Lord Tweedmouth has addressed a letter to the secretary of the League calling attention to the statement explanatory of the Naval Estimates for 1906 7. From that it would be seen, that as far as the numbers were concerned no change of policy has taken place. The letter proceeds: "The original agreement was that this country should only pay for a limited number of Colo nial Royal reservists, and it would be clearly impossible when the seamen of the Royal Naval Reserve at home are being reduced to go beyond the stipulated number. With refe rence to service in men of war, advocated by Lord Goscher, I may point out that a certain number of Newfoundland reserve men are serving in Commodore Paget's squadron which will arrive in this country early in April."

div.head: CREDIT LYONNAIS
div.p: Société Anonyme
Capital 250,000,000 de francs
Entièrement Versés
Agences d'Égypte:
Alexandrie, Le Caire, Port-Said
Le Crédit Lyonnais fait toutes opérations de banque, telles que:
Ouverture de comptes courants contre dépôts de valeurs;
Emission de traites et chèques, émission de lettres de Crédit, paiement par télégraphe sur les principales villes de la France et de l'étranger;
Garde de titres;
Recourvement d'effets sur l'Egypte et l'étranger;
Le Crédit Lyonnais reçoit des fonds ou un compte de dépôt et délivre des bons à échéance fixe aux taux suivants:
2% aux bons de 1 an et au-delà.
